author: Good Enough
description:
In medieval Europe, a trip to the barber was far more intense than choosing a hairstyle. In this video, I uncover the shocking and often gruesome duties performed by medieval barbers, who acted as surgeons, dentists, and all-purpose medical practitioners long before modern medicine existed.

We begin with the era’s strange and symbolic haircuts, including the monk’s tonsure, the fearsome Norman haircut, and the long, wild zazzera style, cuts that could reveal a man’s profession, religion, or social rank. But aesthetic grooming was only a fraction of their work.

Medieval barbers also performed enemas as a common “cure-all,” treating everything from stomach problems to fevers. They handled broken bones, resetting and splinting limbs with primitive tools and frightening accuracy. Their most infamous task, bloodletting, was believed to balance the body’s humors, often leaving patients weaker than before.
